descriptions.description: The data is delivered in an input format which can be used in the GenAlEx 6.5 software (Peakall and Smouse 2006, 2012) http://biology-assets.anu.edu.au/GenAlEx/Welcome.html, from where the data can be exported to various other formats. In the first row of the spreadsheet are given numbers which characterize the data: cell A1=”6” says that there are 6 SSR markers, B1=”721” says that there are 721 samples in total, C1=”29” says that there are 29 provenances in the data set. Cell D1=”22” until cell AF1=”27” give the number of samples in each of the 29 provenances. AG=”1” says that there is one region as a starting point. Finally cell AH=”721”says that there are 721 sample sin this single region. In row no. 2 is given information about the data and the names/numbers of the 29 provenances (corresponding to the ones used in the publication) are given in the cells D2 to AF2. In row no. 3 are given headings for the data columns. “Sample No.” (column 1) is an arbitrary number for the samples within provenances. This is not a unique number; several samples have the same sample no. (e.g. “1”). “Population” is the name/number of the provenances. In the following 12 columns (2 for each of the 6 SSRs) the SSR data is coming in the form of alleles coded as their integer size in base pairs (bp). So in column C and D (starting in cells C4 and D4) are the data for the SSR marker 1TA06, etc.
